subject: Education
title: Norm-Referenced vs. Criterion-Referenced Tests
description: Learn Norm-Referenced vs. Criterion-Referenced Tests in one minute.

hook.text: Are you smart, or just smarter than everyone else in the room? Two test types answer different questions.

buildup.text: Norm-referenced tests rank students against each other; criterion-referenced measure against a standard.

discovery.text: Grading on a curve (norm-referenced) means someone must failâ€”even if everyone mastered the material.

twist.text: Driver's license tests are criterion-referenced: you either can drive safely or you can't. Rankings don't matter.

climax.text: Criterion-referenced tests align better with learning goals: can you do the thing, yes or no?

punchline.text: The question isn't 'are you better?' It's 'are you good enough?'

quiz.question: What is the main difference between norm-referenced and criterion-referenced tests?
options: Norm-referenced ranks students against each other; criterion-referenced measures against a fixed standard
Norm-referenced is harder; criterion-referenced is easier
They produce identical results in all cases
